Global Inequality of Opportunity
entry.summary: Living conditions are vastly unequal between different places in our world today. Today’s global inequality of opportunity means that what matters most for your living conditions is the good or bad luck of your place of birth. We look at how where you’re born is the strongest determinant of your standard of living, whether in life expectancy, income or education.

entry.title: Diarrheal diseases are still a leading cause of child deaths: How many more lives could ORT save?
entry.summary: Diarrheal diseases remain one of the leading causes of deaths in children. One simple intervention – oral rehydration therapy (ORT) – has saved millions of children in recent decades. Yet it can still do more. We look at the future potential of ORT; barriers to its use; and how many lives it could potentially save.

entry.title: Oral rehydration therapy: a low-tech solution that has saved millions of lives
entry.summary: The world has made significant progress in recent decades in reducing deaths from diarrheal diseases, particularly for children. One of the most successful interventions has been oral rehydration therapy (ORT): a simple salt, water and sugar solution. We look at what ORT is, how it was developed, and how many lives it might have saved.

entry.title: Rotavirus vaccine – an effective tool that prevents children dying from diarrhea
entry.summary: Diarrheal diseases are one the largest killers of children, responsible for more than half a million child deaths in 2017. Rotavirus is the leading cause of diarrheal deaths in children. There is, however, an effective tool against it: the rotavirus vaccine. We look at rotavirus vaccine coverage across the world; the estimated number of lives saved and its potential to save more children.

entry.title: More than half a million children die from diarrhea each year. How do we prevent this?
entry.summary: Despite being treatable and preventable, 1.6 million people died from diarrheal diseases in 2017; one-third were children under five years old. This makes it one of the largest killers of children. Here we look at where and why children are dying from diarrrheal diseases, and what we can do stop this.

entry.title: What are children dying from and what can we do about it?
entry.summary: 15,000 children under five years old die every day. To reduce this figure we need to understand what children are dying from, and what interventions are available to stop this. Here we look at the number of children dying by each cause – from pneumonia to diarrheal diseases, malaria and malnutrition. We also present the range of interventions that are available to prevent children from dying.
